item.title: How A Gene Editing Tool Went From Labs To A Middle-School Classroom
item.description: May 27, 2017 - Some compare the democratization of personal computing in the 1970s to the current changes in access to genetic engineering tools, in part thanks to the CRISPR gene editing tool.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 27, 2017 - Some compare the democratization of personal computing in the 1970s to the current changes in access to genetic engineering tools, in part thanks to the CRISPR gene editing tool. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/27/530210657/how-a-gene-editing-tool-went-from-labs-to-a-middle-school-classroom

item.title: U.K.'s Anti-Terrorism Programs Under Scrutiny
item.description: May 27, 2017 - Some of the U.K. government's responses to terrorism have been controversial. Scott Simon speaks with Clive Walker of the University of Leeds, part of a team of independent policy reviewers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 27, 2017 - Some of the U.K. government's responses to terrorism have been controversial. Scott Simon speaks with Clive Walker of the University of Leeds, part of a team of independent policy reviewers. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/27/530337262/u-k-s-anti-terrorism-programs-under-scrutiny

item.title: After A Terrorist Attack, Social Media Can Cause More Harm Than Good
item.description: May 26, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with Emily Dreyfuss, a reporter for Wired, who explains how sharing information about a terrorist attack on social media helps terrorists spread their message.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with Emily Dreyfuss, a reporter for Wired, who explains how sharing information about a terrorist attack on social media helps terrorists spread their message. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/26/530257519/after-a-terrorist-attack-social-media-can-cause-more-harm-than-good

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg Tells Harvard Graduates To Embrace Globalism, 'A Sense Of Purpose'
item.description: May 26, 2017 - The Facebook CEO said fighting authoritarianism and nationalism is "the struggle of our time." Some have speculated he may run for office, though Zuckerberg has denied it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - The Facebook CEO said fighting authoritarianism and nationalism is "the struggle of our time." Some have speculated he may run for office, though Zuckerberg has denied it. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/26/530159142/mark-zuckerberg-tells-harvard-graduates-to-embrace-globalism-a-sense-of-purpose

item.title: Google A.I. Clinches Series Against Humanity's Last, Best Hope To Win At Go
item.description: May 25, 2017 - Ke Jie is a wunderkind — the 19-year-old undisputed master of what might well be the world's most complex game. And he just soundly lost a best-of-three series to an artificial intelligence program.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - Ke Jie is a wunderkind — the 19-year-old undisputed master of what might well be the world's most complex game. And he just soundly lost a best-of-three series to an artificial intelligence program. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/25/530016562/google-a-i-clinches-series-against-humanitys-last-best-hope-to-win-at-go

item.title: Computer Wins Again In Chinese Game Of Go
item.description: May 25, 2017 - Google's AlphaGo program has won two games against Chinese player Ke Jie in the game of go, which has billions of possible moves and had been hard for computers to play.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - Google's AlphaGo program has won two games against Chinese player Ke Jie in the game of go, which has billions of possible moves and had been hard for computers to play. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/25/529977203/computer-wins-again-in-chinese-game-of-go

item.title: Should The Police Control Their Own Body Camera Footage?
item.description: May 25, 2017 - There is a growing perception that body cameras, now generating millions of hours of footage, are there less to keep tabs on police, and more to keep tabs on the public.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - There is a growing perception that body cameras, now generating millions of hours of footage, are there less to keep tabs on police, and more to keep tabs on the public. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/25/529905669/should-the-police-control-their-own-body-camera-footage

item.title: Fitness Trackers: Good at Measuring Heart Rate, Not So Good At Measuring Calories
item.description: May 24, 2017 - A study of seven popular fitness trackers found they are generally good at measuring heart rate, but may mislead consumers about how many calories they have burned.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - A study of seven popular fitness trackers found they are generally good at measuring heart rate, but may mislead consumers about how many calories they have burned. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/24/529839681/fitness-trackers-good-at-measuring-heart-rate-not-so-good-at-measuring-calories

item.title: After Manchester, Social Media Helps And Hurts, Venues Stay Alert And Shows Go On
item.description: May 24, 2017 - In the wake of the bombing on Monday night at an Ariana Grande concert, venues have stepped up security, a promoter laments the imperfect security and social media is useful and harmful — again.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 24, 2017 - In the wake of the bombing on Monday night at an Ariana Grande concert, venues have stepped up security, a promoter laments the imperfect security and social media is useful and harmful — again. http://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2017/05/24/529831579/after-manchester-social-media-helps-and-hurts-venues-stay-alert-and-shows-go-on

item.title: 'Like A God,' Google A.I. Beats Human Champ Of Notoriously Complex Go Game
item.description: May 23, 2017 - "Last year, it was still quite humanlike when it played," the world's No. 1 Go player, Ke Jie, said after losing the first in a three-match series. "But this year, it became like a god of Go."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 23, 2017 - "Last year, it was still quite humanlike when it played," the world's No. 1 Go player, Ke Jie, said after losing the first in a three-match series. "But this year, it became like a god of Go." http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/23/529673475/like-a-god-google-a-i-beats-human-champ-of-notoriously-complex-go-game

item.title: At The Dawn Of Recorded Sound, No One Cared
item.description: May 22, 2017 - In the late 19th century, French inventor Edouard-Leon Scott de Martinville patented the earliest known sound recording device. But his accomplishments were only recognized recently.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 22, 2017 - In the late 19th century, French inventor Edouard-Leon Scott de Martinville patented the earliest known sound recording device. But his accomplishments were only recognized recently. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/22/529550254/at-the-dawn-of-recorded-sound-no-one-cared

item.title: Federal Computers Dodge Global Malware Attack ... This Time
item.description:
May 22, 2017 - Experts say federal agencies have taken steps to secure networks, but they remain vulnerable.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/05/22/529518708/federal-computers-dodge-global-malware-attack-this-time
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: At 94, Lithium-Ion Pioneer Eyes A New Longer-Lasting Battery
item.description: May 22, 2017 - In 1980, John Goodenough's work led to the lithium-ion battery, now found in everything from phones to electric cars. He and fellow researchers say they've come up with a faster-charging alternative.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 22, 2017 - In 1980, John Goodenough's work led to the lithium-ion battery, now found in everything from phones to electric cars. He and fellow researchers say they've come up with a faster-charging alternative. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/22/529116034/at-94-lithium-ion-pioneer-eyes-a-new-longer-lasting-battery

item.title: Feeling Sidelined By Mainstream Social Media, Far-Right Users Jump To Gab
item.description: May 21, 2017 - Criticized for being affiliated with the alt-right, the social site Gab now reports 170,000 users. It has found a niche among some conservatives and others who feel stifled by Facebook and Twitter.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 21, 2017 - Criticized for being affiliated with the alt-right, the social site Gab now reports 170,000 users. It has found a niche among some conservatives and others who feel stifled by Facebook and Twitter. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/21/529005840/feeling-sidelined-by-mainstream-social-media-far-right-users-jump-to-gab

item.title: Don't Feed Parrots Chocolate, Despite What Happens In Minecraft
item.description: May 20, 2017 - In the game Minecraft, a chocolate chip cookie will tame a parrot, but they're poisonous to the birds in real life. Minecraft has promised to update the game.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 20, 2017 - In the game Minecraft, a chocolate chip cookie will tame a parrot, but they're poisonous to the birds in real life. Minecraft has promised to update the game. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/20/529257386/dont-feed-parrots-chocolate-despite-what-happens-in-minecraft
